conclusion: Identify the problem involves an ideal gas changing states with a given p-V diagram and temperature at state A.
The x-axis is volume (V) in units of 10^-3 m³, and the y-axis is pressure (p) in units of 10^5 Pa. Points A, B, and C are marked.
Point A: pressure = 3 × 10^5 Pa, volume = 1 × 10^-3 m³.
Point B: pressure = 1 × 10^5 Pa, volume = 1 × 10^-3 m³.
Point C: pressure = 1 × 10^5 Pa, volume = 3 × 10^-3 m³.
From A to B, volume is constant; pressure decreases. From B to C, pressure is constant; volume increases.
Use the ideal gas law: pV = nRT.
Convert temperature at A from Celsius to Kelvin: T_A = 300 K.
Identify the process from A to B as isochoric (constant volume).
For isochoric process, use p1/T1 = p2/T2.
Calculate T_B using p_A / T_A = p_B / T_B: T_B = 100 K.
Convert T_B from Kelvin to Celsius: T_B = -173.15°C.
Re-examine calculation and confirm T_B = 100 K.
Consider using the general gas equation: pV/T = constant.
Confirm T_B = 100 K using p_A / T_A = p_B / T_B.
